Back: An a posteriori argument claiming that the order, complexity and purpose of the universe imply an intelligent designer (God).
An argument based on observation and experience of the world rather than pure reason.

Front: What analogy does Paley use in the Design Argument?
Back: The watch found on a heath: complex parts working together imply a designer, just as the world implies God.
It draws a probable conclusion about God based on observed evidence, rather than offering absolute proof.

Front: One strength of Paley’s Design Argument
Back: It is intuitive and accessible, as it relies on common-sense observations of order and purpose.

Front: Hume: one criticism of the analogy
Back: The universe is unique, so we cannot confidently compare it to human-made objects like watches.
Even if the world has a designer, it does not follow that this designer is the God of classical theism.
If complexity requires a designer, then God would also require a designer.
Darwin’s theory of natural selection explains apparent design without requiring a divine designer.

Front: One response to evolution from theists
Back: Evolution may explain biological complexity, but not the origin or fine-tuning of the universe itself.
The claim that the universe’s physical constants are precisely calibrated for life, suggesting intentional design.

Front: How does Tennant modify the Design Argument?
Back: Tennant focuses on the universe’s suitability for life rather than biological analogy.

Front: Overall evaluation of the Design Argument
Back: The argument is persuasive to some but weakened by scientific explanations and philosophical criticisms.
